user_message:
Target function code is:
```c
static void
MHD_ip_count_lock (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
{
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->master);
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->per_ip_connection_mutex);
#else
  (void) daemon;
#endif
}
```

List additional symbols that are required to analyze the target function to determine if the target function code violates the following MISRA C rule:
Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly. 
The list will be included in the prompt for the next agent, so be concise and clear.
Explain why each symbol is required in the analysis of the target function for the MISRA C rule.
explanation: mhd_assert: the source uses mhd_assert; you must see its macro expansion to know whether it expands to a function call (which could participate in a recursion path) or to something like a compile-time check / builtin (it likely expands to a check that calls __builtin_unreachable). __builtin_unreachable: the call graph shows this builtin as a callee; confirm it is a compiler builtin (not a normal function) and therefore cannot cause a call back to MHD_ip_count_lock. MHD_mutex_lock_chk_: this is the actual function called (when thread support macros are set). You must inspect its implementation (and its transitive callees) to determine whether it can call, directly or indirectly, MHD_ip_count_lock (or any function that leads back to it). struct MHD_Daemon (definition): the function accesses daemon->per_ip_connection_mutex and daemon->master; you must see the struct definition to ensure per_ip_connection_mutex is not a function pointer or a type that can invoke callbacks that lead back to MHD_ip_count_lock. MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS and MHD_USE_W32_THREADS (compile-time macros): these determine which branch is compiled. Knowing their settings is necessary to decide whether MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ is actually invoked (and thus whether its call-chain must be analyzed for recursion).
